title: Nikolay Moiseyev
text:
Nikolay Dmitriyevich Moiseyev (; December 3(16), 1902 in <a href="Perm%2C%20Russia">Perm</a> – December 6, 1955 in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>) was a <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> <a href="astronomer">astronomer</a> and expert in <a href="celestial%20mechanics">celestial mechanics</a>. In 1938, he became the chairman of the department of celestial mechanics at <a href="Moscow%20State%20University">Moscow State University</a> and worked on this position until his death. His main works were devoted to mathematical methods of celestial calculations and theory of <a href="comet">comet</a> formation.
He also taught <a href="higher%20mathematics">higher mathematics</a> in <a href="Zhukovsky%20Military%20Academy">Zhukovsky Military Academy</a> and was a <a href="colonel">colonel</a>-<a href="engineer">engineer</a> of <a href="Air%20force">Air force</a>s. He was the director of State Astronomic Institute named by Sternberg (1939-1943) and organized the national system of radio-signals for the exact time.
His awards include <a href="Order%20of%20Lenin">Order of Lenin</a>, <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Great%20Patriotic%20War">Order of the Great Patriotic War</a> and two <a href="Red%20Star">Red Star</a>s.
The <a href="Impact%20crater">crater</a> <a href="Moiseev%20%28crater%29">Moiseev</a> on the <a href="Moon">Moon</a> is named after him. A <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> <a href="3080%20Moisseiev">3080 Moisseiev</a> discovered by Soviet astronomer <a href="Pelageya%20Shajn">Pelageya Shajn</a> in 1935 is named after him.
